Re: the yellow color after contact with sulfuric acid:

PBr3 + 2 H2SO4 --> S2Br2 + H3PO4 + HBr

The disulfur dibromide is a deep orange color. It boils at 54° and distills over.

The initial products are H3PO3 + HOBr, but the oxidizing power of HOBr renders P(V) and HBr.

I'm assuming that the PBr3 brominated the sulfuric acid to form sulfuryl bromide (SO2Br2), which should be a yellowish liquid like thionyl chloride. Sulfuryl chloride, its chlorine counterpart, has a low boiling point and would probably not boil over with PBr3 considering its low BP, but it wouldn't surprise me if the bromide came over higher, perhaps even formed an azeotrope, with PBr3

My idea from the knowledge I have:
-Minimal amount of water in the sulphuric acid is present (~3%), it reacted and made H3PO4 in a strong concentration, almost anhydrous, which is extremely hygroscopic
-Ripped off water from the sulphuric acid itself and started over in a chain reaction until the H3PO4 had enough water to prevent it from breaking up even more acid.
You created a self maintaining but then self-stopping reaction. Which is damn awesome!

This is just an educated guess, but I believe the reason the PBr3 turned yellow after introducing sulfuric acid is that the phosphorus tribromide brominates the "hydroxyls" of the sulfuric acid, giving bromosulfuric acid and sulfuryl bromide. (This is analagous to the way phsophorus pentachloride chlorinates sulfuric acid, ie PCl5 + SO2(OH)2 → ClSO3H + POCl3 + HCl. These bromosulfuric (BrSO3H and SO2Br2) compounds are unstable above their melting point (which is below room temperature), and decompose into sulfuric acid, sulfur dioxide, and bromine. The sulfur dioxide escapes, but the sulfuric acid goes on to decompose a further unit of PBr3, meaning it has an effect much larger than the small contamination introduced would imply. The bromine decomposition product is fully miscible with the PBr3 and imparts a yellow color. This would also explain why the yellow color persists even after adding water; the bromine is unreactive with any of the other products and forms a light bromine-water yellow color.
